Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial on Fiberoptic Intubation in Simulated Cervical Spine Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: Sixty adult patients requiring nasotracheal intubation for oral surgery were randomly assigned

Participants.evidence: Sixty adult patients requiring nasotracheal intubation for oral surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to continuous positive-pressure oxygen (CPO), normal-pressure (NS), or intermittent negative-pressure suction (INS) groups

Objective.evidence: aimed to evaluate the efficiency and safety of fiberoptic intubation under different air pressures

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was intubation time, measured from bronchoscope insertion to tracheal intubation completion, with a maximum of 180 seconds

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed in sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to the outcome assessor

Result_Outcome.evidence: The median intubation time was significantly shorter in the CPO group (59 seconds) compared to the NS (167 seconds) and INS (132.5 seconds) groups (P=0.04)
